results.title: A Heritage to build on
results.creator_credit: Derek Williams, Humphrey Swingler and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Made as part of the Cement and Concrete Association’s contribution to European Architectural Heritage Year 1975, shows the many types of Britain’s old and modern architecture. It contrasts the present time, when renewal and renovation of urban environment is a matter of concern, with the past. It shows that with thoughtful use of today’s materials such as concrete, old and modern buildings can be compatible with those of the past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Derek Williams, Humphrey Swingler and Greenpark Productions

results.title: A Fortunate life
results.brief_description: A Fortunate Life, the remarkable story of Bert Facey, an ordinary Australian whose extraordinary life spans some of the most significant historical milestones along Australia’s path to nationhood. Adapted from the best selling novel, “A Fortunate Life”, Facey’s experiences constitute a moving saga from his harsh early days as a child on the goldfields of Kalgoorlie, through his adolescence as a bushman in rugged North-West Australia, to the savage bloody carnage on the beaches of Gallipoli. Through it all Bert Facey remains optimistic and totally without cynicism. “A Fortunate Life” is an inspirational tale of one man’s struggle against seemingly overwhelming barriers to achieve peace and contentment. Rated: PG

results.title: A Foreign language
results.creator_credit: Stanley Jackson, Roman Kroitor, Tom Daly, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film observes, in a Montreal public school, the teaching of English to immigrant children. To thousands of children arriving in Canada from Greece, Italy, France, Germany or Japan, English is “a foreign language.” Under able coaching they begin to understand and even enjoy the vagaries of the English language.

results.title: A Force more powerful: a century of non-violent conflict
results.creator_credit: Steve York, WETA-TV and York Zimmerman
results.brief_description: Explores the use of nonviolent action in the fight for human rights around the world during the 20th century. Mohandas Gandhi, inspired by the Russian Revolution of 1905, fully believed in nonviolence as a means of fighting back against any form of oppression or brutality. Three broad classes of nonviolent methods exist: nonviolent protest and persuasion, noncooperation, and nonviolent intervention. “A Force more powerful” presents six stories demonstrating successful nonviolent means of overcoming conflict. “India: defying the Crown” 1930-31 - Gandhi led the fight for independence using civil disobedience on a massive scale, challenging the British tax and monopoly on salt. “Nashville: we were warriors” 1960-61 - Students led by Reverend James Lawson staged sit-ins and boycotts to eliminate segregation in Nashville, a city of two races. “Poland: we’ve caught God by the arm” 1980-81 - A strike, organised by Lech Walesa, and the workers in the shipyard at Gdansk led to the birth of the Solidarity movement and the fight for recognition of trade unions. “South Africa: freedom in our lifetime” 1985-86 - Youth organiser, Mkhuseli Jack, brought together the various Black civil action groups and arranged a consumer boycott of the white businesses in Port Elizabeth in an attempt to end apartheid. “Denmark: living with the enemy” 1940-45 - Although the Danish Government proclaimed neutrality status during World War II, they were still occupied by the Nazis. A facade of co-operation covered a growing active resistance, a resistance which eventually led to sabotage and labor strikes. “Chile: defeat of a dictator” 1983-88 - General Augusto Pinochet’s brutal dictatorship and military rule was gradually undermined by the Chilean people staging a national protest day and months and years of nonviolent demonstrations. Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by Ben Kingsley.

Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by Ben Kingsley.

results.title: A Filmmaker's Journey
results.brief_description: Superlative documentary tracing the career if one of Hollywood’s most acclaimed and ambitious directors, George Stevens. Unlike other similar documentaries, this is not a mere star studded exercise in hero worship; a real sense of the director’s personality emerges. Excerpts from many of his films are used, including “Giant”, “Shane”, “Gunga Din”, and “The Diary of Anne Frank”. This tribute was written and directed by Stevens’ son.

results.title: A Fair cop
results.creator_credit: Craig Kirchner, John Cruthers, Steven Salgo, Film Victoria and Seon Film Productions
results.brief_description: A film, for young people to see, that emphasises road safety for cyclists. The film is a fictional dramatisation of a policeman on patrol who encounters some careless riders.

results.title: A Doll's house: by Henrik Ibsen
results.creator_credit: Patrick Garland, Hillard Elkins and Elkins Productions
results.brief_description: Ibsen’s feminist play set is Norway depicts Nora Helmer (Claire Bloom), a woman struggling for independence within her marriage, and against her husband’s will (played by Anthony Hopkins). In the face of male obstinacy and arrogance she sets off in search of her own life and destiny and breaks the shackles which have persisted in treating her as if she were a doll. Cast includes Denholm Elliot, Ralph Richardson and Edith Evans. Another version of Ibsens’s play, directed by Joseph Losey was released in the same year starring Jane Fonda and David Werner.

results.title: A Director talks about his film
results.creator_credit: David Grotenstein, Peter Riegert, Susan Krebs and Prospective Films
results.brief_description: A satirical film depicting an interview with an Italian film director, Aldo Altonandino who’s remarks in Italian are translated into English by a deadpanned, uninvolved female interpreter. As he gets carried away by his pseudo-eloquence the translator continues in robot-like fashion. As the camera pulls back, the real director appears explaining his idea for the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Grotenstein, Peter Riegert, Susan Krebs and Prospective Films

results.title: A Handful of dust
results.creator_credit: Charles Sturridge, Derek Granger, New Line Cinema and Stagescreen
results.brief_description: Tony and Brenda Last (James Wilby and Kristin Scott Thomas) appear to be the perfect married ccouple - with money, position, a great country house and an adored son, John Andrew. When Tony inadvertently invites John Beaver (Rupert Graves), an idle and penniless young socialite, to stay for the weekend, he sets in motion a series of events which drastically disrupts the course of all their lives. Brenda drifts into an affair with the worthless Mr. Beaver, with disastrous consequences, particularly for Tony, who remains unaware of Brenda’s betrayal until the tragic death of their young son. As Brenda leaves home to take up a precarious life with her lover in London. Tony sets sail with an eccentric explorer on an expedition to the South American rain forests. Lost in the jungle and stricken by fever, Tony is rescued from death by the eccentric Mr. Todd (Alec Guinness) with unexpected and sinister results.
